plugins.name: View Overrides
plugins.description:
This plugin allows you to get an overview of overrides in your layers.


How to use

  1. Select a layer or multiple layers
  2. Run plugin
  3. Selecting layers will navigate to them
  4. The overrides will update periodically if you fix or edit them.
  5. To change selection run the plugin again.


If you find this plugin useful feel free to buy me a slice of pizza

plugins.name: Genome Import
plugins.description:
Create color palettes for all themes of your design system with meaningfully weighted numbers.


The genome color tool


Easy to use

No curves, graphs, or sliders required. Just input brand colors and let Genome create tints and shades for you.


Multiple Palette Systems

Choose palette systems from the most popular design systems, or create your own starting with Univers optimization.


Built for Accessibility

Reliable Contrast Pass/Fail using CIELab L* density values as numeric weight of the palette system.


Open Source

Code for the Figma plugin and Genome web app are free for download

plugins.name: Text Pro  - Bulk Editing for Figma Text Fields
plugins.description:
Text Pro is the ultimate Figma plugin for powerful bulk editing of text fields. Add prefixes, suffixes, sequential numbers, or alphabetical markers (ascending or descending) with precision and ease. Find and replace text across multiple fields, or transform your content using flexible controls.


Features:

  1. Find & Replace: Efficiently search and update text across multiple fields.
  2. Add Numbers: Create ascending or descending sequences with customizable start, stop, and increment values.
  3. Add Alphabetical Markers: Apply ascending or descending letters with adjustable start or stop points.


Whether you're streamlining layouts, cleaning up designs, or standardizing a design system, Text Pro saves you time and effort while enhancing your workflow.

plugins.name: Variable Doc
plugins.description:
Simplify your Figma workflow with Variable Doc â€” the ultimate tool for managing and documenting your variables effortlessly.

Whether you're working with local variables or shared library variables, this plugin provides a seamless way to view, filter, and organize everything in one place.


All Your Variables, One View

Easily access a clear and organized overview of all your Figma variables, including both local and library variables, without navigating through multiple menus.


Search and Filter by Type

Quickly find the variables you need with intuitive search and filter options. Filter by type â€” Color, Number, String, or Boolean â€” to keep your workflow efficient and focused.


One-Click Documentation

Choose from 3 distinct styles, all designed with Auto Layout for a polished and organized presentation. Perfect for sharing with your team or clients, ensuring everyone stays on the same page.


Eliminate hours of manual work by automating variable management and documentation. Spend less time organizing and more time designing!


Enjoy using Variable Doc, and if you encounter any issues or have questions, feel free to reach out via email.


Currently, this is the beta release of version 1.0. We're actively working on fixing minor bugs and planning to add exciting new features in the near future. Stay tuned for updates!

plugins.name: Vectorizer - Auto Trace Batch Images
plugins.description:
Easily convert selected bitmap layers (such as PNG/JPG images) into scalable black-and-white vectors with a single click. This plugin sends your selected images to a secure cloud-based vectorization service and automatically places the resulting SVG next to the original image, preserving layout and alignment.


Key Features:


âœ… One-click conversion of Bitmap-based into vector

âœ… Places the vector result neatly to the right of the original image

âœ… Supports batch processing of multiple images at once

âœ… Lightweight UI and seamless integration with Figma workflow


This plugin is ideal for designers who need to vectorize hand-drawn sketches, scanned artwork, or raster logos without leaving Figma.
plugins.tagline: Convert Images into Vector Black and White with one click

plugins.name: Grayscale Wireframe Converter
plugins.description: Effortlessly convert your Figma designs into professional grayscale wireframes with the Grayscale Wireframe Converter. Perfect for UX designers and product teams, this plugin transforms selected elements or entire pages into clean, monochromatic wireframes with a single click. It simplifies colors to grayscale for a polished, distraction-free look. Small containers get darker grays for contrast, while larger elements use lighter shades, ensuring readability and hierarchy. Images are replaced with light gray placeholders, and text is optimized for clarity. No network access is required, making it fast and secure. Whether you're iterating on early concepts or presenting low-fidelity prototypes, this plugin streamlines your workflow. Select your design, click "Convert to Wireframe," and watch your vision transform into a stunning grayscale wireframe. Try it now and elevate your process!
plugins.tagline: Transform designs into sleek grayscale wireframes instantly

plugins.name: Style Reptile: Figma to CSS Extractor
plugins.description:
Style Reptile: Figma to CSS Extractor


This plugin generates CSS styles from Figma styles and variables in adaptive way: using mobile (m) and desktop (d) values:

  • Spaces
  • Typography


Spaces


Input

  1. Create a collection named screen
  2. Create a 2 modes in it: m for mobile values and d for desktop values
  3. Add spacing variables prefixed with space- of 'Number' type to use as CSS variables in the generation output
  4. Run the plugin


Output

As an output the following will be generated:

1. Root variables in the config.css file:

:root {
  --space-xxl: 9rem; /* 1rem = 10px to convenient conversion */
  --space-xl: 6rem;
  --space-l: 4rem;
  --space-m: 3rem;
  --space-s: 2.5rem;
  --space-xs: 2rem;
  --space-xxs: 1.5rem;
}

@media (min-width: 640px) {
  :root {
    --space-xxl: 15rem;
    --space-xl: 10rem;
    --space-l: 8rem;
    --space-m: 6rem;
    --space-s: 4rem;
    --space-xs: 3rem;
    --space-xxs: 2rem;
  }
}

2. Paddings and margins classnames in paddings.css and margins.css:

/* All */

.p-xxl {
  padding: var(--space-xxl);
}
.p-xl {
  padding: var(--space-xl);
}
/* ... */

/* X */

.px-xxl {
  padding-left: var(--space-xxl);
  padding-right: var(--space-xxl);
}
/* ... */

/* Top */

.pt-xxl {
  padding-top: var(--space-xxl);
}
/* ... and so on */
  • p-* / m-* â€” padding / margin all
  • px-* / mx-* â€” padding / margin left and right
  • py-* / my-* â€” padding / margin top and bottom
  • pt-* / mt-* â€” padding / margin top
  • pr-* / mr-* â€” padding / margin right
  • pb-* / mb-* â€” padding / margin bottom
  • pl-* / ml-* â€” padding / margin left


Typography


Input

  1. Name the text styles by following the pattern m/* for mobile and d/* for desktop
  2. Run the plugin


Output

As an output the following will be generated:

1. Root variables in the config.css file:

:root {
  --text-xxl: normal 400 4rem/1 'Inter';
  --text-xl: normal 400 3rem/1 'Inter';
  --text-l: normal 400 1.8rem/1.05 'Inter';
  --text-m: normal 400 1.3rem/1.2 'Inter';
}

    --text-m: normal 400 2.2rem/1.2 'Inter';

}

.text-xxl {
  font: var(--text-xxl);
}
.text-xl {
  font: var(--text-xl);
}
.text-l {
  font: var(--text-l);
}

83546.name: Style Reptile: Figma to CSS Extractor
83546.description:
Style Reptile: Figma to CSS Extractor


This plugin generates CSS styles from Figma styles and variables in adaptive way: using mobile (m) and desktop (d) values:

  • Spaces
  • Typography


Spaces


Input

  1. Create a collection named screen
  2. Create a 2 modes in it: m for mobile values and d for desktop values
  3. Add spacing variables prefixed with space- of 'Number' type to use as CSS variables in the generation output
  4. Run the plugin


Output

As an output the following will be generated:

1. Root variables in the config.css file:

:root {
  --space-xxl: 9rem; /* 1rem = 10px to convenient conversion */
  --space-xl: 6rem;
  --space-l: 4rem;
  --space-m: 3rem;
  --space-s: 2.5rem;
  --space-xs: 2rem;
  --space-xxs: 1.5rem;
}

@media (min-width: 640px) {
  :root {
    --space-xxl: 15rem;
    --space-xl: 10rem;
    --space-l: 8rem;
    --space-m: 6rem;
    --space-s: 4rem;
    --space-xs: 3rem;
    --space-xxs: 2rem;
  }
}

2. Paddings and margins classnames in paddings.css and margins.css:

/* All */

.p-xxl {
  padding: var(--space-xxl);
}
.p-xl {
  padding: var(--space-xl);
}
/* ... */

/* X */

.px-xxl {
  padding-left: var(--space-xxl);
  padding-right: var(--space-xxl);
}
/* ... */

/* Top */

.pt-xxl {
  padding-top: var(--space-xxl);
}
/* ... and so on */

  3. Exposure Slider: Control the overall brightness level.
  4. Monochrome Color Selection: Choose any monochrome color, not just black-n-white.
  5. Filled Alpha Mode: Define the underlying fill color when using the Filled Alpha mode.

plugins.name: Copy That
plugins.description:
Manage your copy magically using Figma Variables.


We've all been there.

Your developer looks at the android and iOS versions of your screen, and tells you the copy doesn't match the web version. It should. You would normally despair as you painstakingly update each text layer individually and pray you didn't miss something else.


Despair NO MORE!


This plugin will help your copy stay in sync between screens, and makes updating that copy a breeze!


Import text as Figma variables right from your Figma frames. Then link other text layers to those variables so that when you update that variable, all your text layers get updated automatically and never go out of sync.


This does NOT require a paid version of Figma - will work with the free version.


Happy Figma-ing!


Brad

accepted.name: Brad Judd
accepted.description: I'm a designer at Turo. Always tinkering.

plugins.tagline: Your brain for managing copy in Figma

plugins.name: Falcon
plugins.description:
Falcon is an experimental ChatGPT powered Figma plugin that allows you to quickly search for layers using natural language descriptions.


Simply make a selection, then describe a condition that each layer has to follow to remain selected. The plugin will apply that filter to every layer you've selected, and optionally to every child as well, streamlining your workflow and saving you time.


No one likes searching through layers to manually select a bunch of layers in a messy figma file. Now you don't have to.


You'll just need an OpenAI API key to get started, which you can get here after making an account.


Tips:

  • Be descriptive: It's more likely to get you what you want if you're descriptive and specific. It's powered by ChatGPT so if you've used that before, write in a similar way.
  • It doesn't know what you've selected: As a measure to both increase privacy and reduce token usage, I've built it to not rely on knowing what you've got selected, so don't write any rules that expect it to have that understanding. For example, don't write "is the name of an animal" (I tried it once to see what would happen and it tried to make a list of every animal to make a comparison, and it hit the token limit so didn't finish.)
  • It does some things really well, and other things not at all: It currently struggles with vague references to colors and gradients. If you want to query those, be specific, i.e. don't say "is red", instead use a hex code, list of hex codes/rgba/hsla etc or describe a range of values that should pass. For gradients, "has a gradient" doesn't work reliably. Instead, say something like "has a linear gradient fill".


This is still very much an experimental plugin, so expect it to not work perfectly every single time. My twitter DMs are open if you encounter any issues though.
plugins.tagline: Filter and select layers by describing what you want

plugins.name: ClarityUX: Predictive Eye-Tracking, AI Heatmaps & Usability Insights for UX Designers
plugins.description:
ClarityUX: Predictive Eye-Tracking, AI Heatmaps & Usability Insights for UX Designers


Transform your UI designs with comprehensive analysis, accessibility insights, and visual attention mapping to boost conversions


ClarityUX is the ultimate design intelligence companion for Figma users seeking to perfect their interfaces. Our powerful AI analyzes your design files to provide actionable improvements, WCAG compliance checks, attention heat-maps, and detailed UX recommendationsâ€”all in one seamless workflow.


ðŸ” Key Features


Comprehensive Design Analysis using Groq and Gemini AI

- Composition Analysis: Get detailed feedback on visual hierarchy, balance, and layout structure

- Design Improvement Suggestions: Receive actionable recommendations to enhance your designs

- UX Enhancement Insights: Uncover opportunities to improve user experience and flow


Attention Heatmaps

- Visual Attention Mapping: See exactly where users will focus their attention

- Focus Area Analysis: Identify key areas drawing user attention and potential blind spots

- Interactive Heatmaps: Dynamically visualize user attention patterns across your designs



Powerful Insights

- Element-by-Element Review: Get detailed feedback on specific components and sections

- Data-Backed Recommendations: All suggestions supported by UX research and best practices

- Export Capabilities: Share insights with your team for collaborative improvement


ðŸ’¯ Benefits


- Save Time: Automate the design review process and focus on creative work

- Improve Quality: Create more user-friendly and accessible designs

- Data-Driven Decisions: Base design choices on objective predictive analysis rather than guesswork

- Learn & Grow: Develop better design instincts through AI-powered feedback


ðŸš€ Getting Started


1. Select design elements you want to analyze

2. Choose which analysis tools to run (Design Review, Heatmap)

3. Review insights and implement suggested improvements


ClarityUX works with all Figma design elements including frames, artboards, groups, and components.


Perfect for UI/UX designers, product teams, and design agencies looking to create exceptional user experiences backed by data and accessibility best practices.


Upgrade your design workflow with ClarityUX today!

[3 free credits Included for new users]

plugins.name: Liquid Glass Distortion
plugins.description:
Liquid Distortion Plugin Instructions


  1. Add an image background in a Figma Frame, then create or select a rectangle or circle layer (currently only supports rectangles and circles).
  2. Open the plugin to see an initial preview of the effect in the top window.
  3. Adjust parameters below to customize the glass texture.
  4. Click insert to apply the final effect to your layer.


Parameter Details

  1. Clarity

Controls the output quality. Higher values produce sharper details but slower processing. Recommended: 2x.

  1. Distortion Range

Controls the radius of the clear central area. Lower values expand the clear zone.

  1. Distortion Strength

Adjusts edge distortion intensity. Higher values increase stretching.

  1. Gaussian Blur

Adds background blur to simulate frosted glass.

  1. Chromatic Aberration

Adds RGB color separation to edges for optical realism.

Additional Features

  1. iOS Style

Adds iOS system styles without overriding existing layer properties.

  1. Live Insert

Dynamically updates effects during parameter adjustments or layer transformations.

*Note: 200ms delay after operations for performance.*

  1. Parameter Memory

Saves parameters per layer. Re-selecting the layer reloads previous settings.

plugins.name: Frame Multiplier with Custom Text
plugins.description:
With this plugin you will be able to generate n Frames from a "Frame template", in addition you will be able to establish different text values for each one of these.


It is recommended that before executing the plugin, clear names are established for the text fields that they want to modify, so that their identification is easy (step 2), each value goes on a line within the textarea.


If you set a number of values greater than 1 for more than one text field, then they must have the same number of values or lines.


With this plugin you will be able to:

  • Generate a batch of certificates, diplomas, etc.
  • Copy or duplicate a frame n times.
  • Set custom names for each generated frame.
plugins.tagline: This plugin allows you multiply a Frame n times and be able to set custom text values for each one.

One useful use case for Figma String variable is design localization or content review (like mentioned in this Youtube video) , but they come with certain drawbacks that this plugin aims to solve.

  1. Creating variables, and attaching variables to text layers is very time consuming for a large design file or a complex prototype
  2. Difficulty in identifying text layers that are without attached variables later on
  3. Not easy to create variables in bulk


Features

  1. Display all visible text under a Figma layer as an editable table
  2. Create and assign variables for each text with ease
  3. Auto create variables in bulk
  4. Search and filter the table to quickly identify a text layer that needs to be assigned a new or existing variable
  5. Import and export the text and variables
  6. Remove unused variables


Playground file

Please see the playground file for more tutorials!


Contact

If you have any questions or feature suggestions, feel free to leave a comment!
plugins.tagline: Easily establish a local Translation Management or Content Review System with Figma variables

This plugin is your new best friend for managing variable scopes in Figma. It's designed to help you quickly filter, search, and modify the scopes of your local variables without breaking a sweat.


What can you do with it?

  1. Filter variables by type: Whether you're looking for NUMBER, COLOR, STRING this plugin's got you covered.

Brutal

plugins.name: Batch Frame Creator
plugins.description:
Effortlessly create and customize Figma frames with specified dimensions and names using this plugin.


Introducing my latest plugin, a personal endeavor aimed at streamlining frame creation like never before. With just a single click, you can now batch-create an infinite number of frames, significantly reducing the time and effort required compared to traditional methods.


Key Features:


  • Unlimited frame creation
  • Optional frame naming for precise organization
  • Customizable frame sizes (height and width)
  • How to Use:


Upon opening the plugin, you'll find two sections of settings:


Frame Settings:


  • Specify the number of frames you wish to add.
  • Optionally name each frame for meticulous management.


Size Settings:


  • Set the width and height for all frames simultaneously.


Please Note: In this version, size adjustments apply universally to all frames.


I'm open to your suggestions and eager to hear about any additional features you'd like to see or modifications you suggest. Your feedback is invaluable to me, so please don't hesitate to reach out or comment.
plugins.tagline: Effortlessly create and customize Figma frames with specified dimensions and names using this plugin

The ultimate plugin for maximizing the utility of comments in Figma


Commentify goes beyond basic annotation toolsâ€”it's your indispensable ally for managing layer annotations seamlessly in Figma. With it, chaotic comment threads are transformed into organized hubs of productivity.


What can you achieve with Commentify?


  • Streamlined annotations: effortlessly create and manage annotations. Categorize your comments based on various aspects (poeditor, accessibility and analytics).

plugins.name: Adeliom WebComponents - For Figma
plugins.description:
Adeliom WebComponents - For Figma is a dedicated plugin designed for enhancing the workflow of Figma users, especially in development mode. This tool is engineered to streamline the design-to-code transition, crucial for modern web development.


Key Features


  1. Variable Extraction: Extracts design variables directly from Figma files.
  2. Format Conversion: Transforms these variables into CSS and JSON formats, ensuring seamless integration.
  3. Compatibility with AWC: Specifically tailored to be fully compatible with Adeliom WebComponents (AWC) design systems.


Benefits


  1. Efficiency in Design Workflow: Significantly reduces the time and effort needed to convert design elements into usable code.
  2. Seamless Integration: Facilitates an effortless transition of design elements into the AWC ecosystem, maintaining design integrity and consistency.
  3. Bridging Design and Development: Ideal for teams seeking a cohesive workflow between designers and developers.


Use Cases


  1. Web Development: Perfect for developers working with complex web components.
  2. UI/UX Design: Assists designers in visualizing how their designs will translate into actual web components.


Demo & Learn More


For a deeper understanding of how Adeliom WebComponents - For Figma integrates with the AWC design systems, visit AWC Design Systems.
plugins.tagline: Transform Figma Variables into CSS and JSON objects for AWC

plugins.name: Cite
plugins.description:
The Cite plugin allows you to add citations from Zotero to your Figma files and FigJam boards. You must have a Zotero account, an API Key, and be online to use the plugin.


To search your private libraries, you'll need to provide the plugin your Zotero User ID and API Key.


Once youâ€™ve added your keys, you can search for anything in your Zotero library. The plugin will return a list of titles and authors. You can select an item from the search results and add it to your layout.


How to use


1. Get your User ID

  • Go to zotero.org/settings/keys and copy your userid. Run the plugin and paste your userid into the pluginâ€™s User ID field.


2. Create an API Key

  • Go back to zotero.org/settings/keys and click â€œCreate new private keyâ€.
  • Fill out the form. Make sure â€œAllow library accessâ€ and â€œRead Onlyâ€ are enabled. Click â€œSave Key.â€
  • Copy the key from the green box. Paste the key into the pluginâ€™s API Key field. Click the â€œSave Keysâ€ button in the plugin.


3. Search your Zotero library

  •  In the plugin, enter a keyword into the search field (e.g., cats) and select an item from the list of search results.


4. Add the selected item to your Figma or FigJam layout

  • Confirm your selection and generate the citation.


Note: The plugin saves your credentials locally, so you do not need to enter this information every time you use it. However, you may need re-enter your credentials if you clear your cache. The plugin does not store your credentials anywhere on the web.


Feedback

How do you use this plugin? How would you like to use it? Any and all feedback is welcome. You can add comments as sticky notes to this FigJam board.


Roadmap

Future enhancements will be based on user feedback. A few ideas:

  • Add notes to a citation
  • Export an image of a source
  • Include tags from sources
  • Create a bibliography


Contribute

If youâ€™d like to help develop this plugin, feel free to submit an issue or pull request. Code contributors should fork the repo and create a working branch for new changes. Once youâ€™ve made changes, you can create a pull request for review.


GitHub repo: https://github.com/jamescoledesign/cite


Some useful guides for contributors:

  • Zotero Web API documentation
  • Figma Plugin API documentation
  • Example contribution guide: GitHub docs contributing guide


Contact

citeplugin@gmail.com
plugins.tagline: Add citations from Zotero to your Figma and FigJam layouts

plugins.name: Autolayout Shortcut Helper
plugins.description:
Quick demo: https://youtu.be/JMY3Xd4Fty4


Provides a way for you to assign keyboard shortcuts for "Space Between" and "Packed" 


AutoLayout is great, I spend all day using it. But I need an easier way to switch between spacing modes. Usually- I have to move my cursor, click a dropdown, and click. This plugin exposes the "Space Between" and "Packed" options to the menubar, making it possible to assign keyboard shortcuts to them.


Definetly a hack, but still useful!!


Thanks @desktopofsamuel for sharing the original asset used in my cover art.

plugins.name: Scoutr:Style Guides Generator
plugins.description:
Scoutr transforms your Figma design files into beautifully organized style guides instantly. Simply select your design elements, and watch as Scoutr automatically analyzes and generates a comprehensive style guide.


Key Features:

  1. Automatic color system analysis with semantic naming
  2. Typography styles documentation with live previews
  3. Shadow effects and gradients categorization
  4. Spacing (Auto-Layout) and radius system detection
  5. Support for px, dp, and pt units


How to Use:

  1. Select the layers or frames you want to analyze
  2. Choose your preferred unit (px/dp/pt)
  3. Click generate and get your style guide instantly!


Perfect for:

  1. Handoff documentation
  2. Design consistency check
  3. Quick style guide creation


Note: Works with any Figma design file. No setup or configuration needed.
